Fire stick shows only 3 max (blu-ray player app showed atleast 12 in one screen) and you have to keep scrolling to find something.Other thing i dont like is making you to buy the HD version by default instead of normal version which is $1 less. you have to go to other ways to watch option to select the cheaper price. thats unlike Amazon.
author: Caprisun

review: My first admission is that I really haven't had time to work with the Fire TV Stick.  Set-up and reception - picture quality are all acceptable.Currently I'm a bit confused with what is free and what I need to pay for.  Example? . . . I wanted to try music - found a selection that looked good.  The final screen before playing said something like "Buy - $2.50"  Now - I did listen - figuring I can afford the $2.50 - but by simply listening at home did I "buy".  Or if I opted for the "buy" option would I be able to download all the songs for my listening pleasure.  I'm sure most people who are more savvy than I am would understand.Screening the movies - even the old ones seemed like there were few - if any - that were free.  I may be wrong - again admitting that I didn't work too long.  But I found the short introductory video unhelpful when it came to explaining what the expenses were going to be as I move forward with this system.  Hopefully when my schedule settles down a bit I can explore and learn more.Bottom Line:  I'm confused with exactly what I bought and why it is anything that I want - especially if I want to access TV or movies at no cost.
author: Eric R Longman

review: Works pretty well.  It compares to many of the other streaming devices out there.  I'm not a big fan of the layout though. I wish the interface was more like my Roku 3.  Does lose signal sometimes and needs to be reset, but that may be an issue with my router.
